|years_active = ~450 years |territory = India |ethnicity = Indian |membership =
|activities = Murder, robbery |allies = |rivals = }} 'Thuggee' (; ; ; ; ), also
known as 'tuggee' refers to the acts of 'thugs', an organized gang of
professional assassins.

The thugs traveled in groups across India for several hundred years. They were
devoted to Kali, a Hindu goddess associated with violence, sexuality, and more
recently, empowerment.<ref name="thugs">"[http://articles.latimes.com/2003/aug/03/travel/tr-
books3 Tracing India's cult of thugs]". 3 August 2003. Los Angeles Times.</ref>

They were first mentioned in the Ẓiyāʾ-ud-Dīn Baranī () dated around 1356.<ref
name="brit">http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/594263/thug</ref>

In the 1830s they were targeted by William Bentinck, along with his chief
captain William Henry Sleeman, for eradication. They were seemingly destroyed by
this effort.<ref name="thugs"/><ref name="cult">http://www.mahavidya.ca/hindu-sects/the-thuggee-
cult/</ref> According to some estimates the Thugs murdered 1 million people
between 1740 and 1840.<ref>{{Cite book
  | last = Rubinstein first = W. D. title = Genocide: a history url = ht-
  | tp://books.google.com/books?id=nMMAk4VwLLwC&pg=&dq#v=onepage&q=&f=fa-
  | lse publisher = Pearson Education year = 2004 pages = 82–83 isbn =
  | 0-582-50601-8 }}
</ref>

The Thugs would join travellers and gain their confidence. This would allow them
to then surprise and strangle their victims by tossing a handkerchief or noose
around their necks. The killings were performed in honour of the Hindu goddess
Kali and were very ritualistic.<ref name="thugs"/> They would then rob their
victims of valuables and bury their bodies. This led them to also be called
'Phansigar' (), a term more commonly used in southern India.<ref
name="RussellLai1995"></ref>

The term Thuggee is derived from Hindi word ठग, or , which means thief.
Related words are the verb thugna, to deceive, from Sanskrit स्थग meaning
cunning, sly, fraudulent, dishonest, scoundrel, from स्थगति
().<ref>[http://www.1902encyclopedia.com/T/THU/thugs.html Thugs]
1902Encyclopædia Britannica.Pali-sthag</ref> This term for a particular kind
of murder and robbery of travellers is popular in South Asia and
particularly in India.

The story of Thuggee was popularised by books such as Philip Meadows Taylor's
novel [[Confessions of a Thug (novel)|Confessions of a Thug]], 1839, leading to
the word "thug" entering the English language.
